The **Georgia Southern Eagles football** program represents [Georgia Southern
University](/wiki/Georgia_Southern_University "Georgia Southern University")
in [football](/wiki/American_football "American football") as part of the [Sun
Belt Conference](/wiki/Sun_Belt_Conference "Sun Belt Conference") under head
coach [Chad Lunsford](/wiki/Chad_Lunsford "Chad Lunsford"). The Eagles have
won six [FCS](/wiki/Division_I-AA#Football_Championship_Subdivision "Division
I-AA") (I-AA) national championships and have produced two [Walter Payton
Award](/wiki/Walter_Payton_Award "Walter Payton Award") winners. The Eagles
first continuously fielded a football team in 1924; however, play was
suspended for [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and revived in
1981. The Eagles competed as an FCS independent from 1984 until 1992 as the
Eagles' main conference at the time, the Trans America Athletic Conference
(now known as the [Atlantic Sun Conference](/wiki/Atlantic_Sun_Conference
"Atlantic Sun Conference")), did not sponsor football, and as a member of the
[Southern Conference](/wiki/Southern_Conference "Southern Conference") from
1993 until 2013, winning 10 SoCon championships. Georgia Southern joined the
[Sun Belt Conference](/wiki/Sun_Belt_Conference "Sun Belt Conference") upon
transitioning to the FBS level in 2014. The Eagles won the [Sun Belt
Conference](/wiki/Sun_Belt_Conference "Sun Belt Conference") championship
outright in its first year as an FBS member. Georgia Southern's main Sun Belt
rival is [Appalachian State](/wiki/Appalachian_State_Mountaineers "Appalachian
State Mountaineers") .

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

See also: [List of Georgia Southern Eagles football
seasons](/wiki/List_of_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_seasons "List of
Georgia Southern Eagles football seasons")

### Early years:
1924–1941[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early years: 1924–1941")]

As First District A&M, the school began organizing football teams as early as
1909.[2] However, the college first continuously fielded a team in 1924. In
1929, B.L. "Crook" Smith, a sports standout from [Mercer
University](/wiki/Mercer_University "Mercer University"), was hired as
football coach and athletics director and would lead the football team for 13
seasons. Football was suspended in 1941 at the outset of World War II and
would not return for 41 years.

### Erk Russell era:
1981–1989[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Erk Russell era: 1981–1989")]

In 1978, President Dale Lick decided that football should be revived at
Georgia Southern College. Despite a faculty senate vote against renewing the
sport, Lick worked to generate support for the endeavor. In 1982, the school
hired [Erk Russell](/wiki/Erk_Russell "Erk Russell"), the popular and
charismatic defensive coordinator at the [University of
Georgia](/wiki/University_of_Georgia "University of Georgia"), to coach the
new football team. On the hire, humorist [Lewis Grizzard](/wiki/Lewis_Grizzard
"Lewis Grizzard") said, "When they landed Erk Russell, they got themselves a
franchise."[3] The Eagles fielded a club team in 1982 and 1983 and began
official [NCAA](/wiki/NCAA "NCAA") Division I-AA play in 1984. The next year,
the Eagles would win their first Division I-AA national championship in
[Tacoma, Washington](/wiki/Tacoma,_Washington "Tacoma, Washington"), defeating
[Furman University](/wiki/Furman_University "Furman University"), in only the
team's fourth year in existence, second as a varsity team. The Eagles would
return to Tacoma the next year and win the championship vs. [Arkansas
State](/wiki/Arkansas_State_University "Arkansas State University"). In 1989,
the Eagles became the first college team to go 15–0 in the 20th century,
winning the national championship on their home field vs. [Stephen F.
Austin](/wiki/Stephen_F._Austin "Stephen F. Austin"). Soon after the game,
Russell retired.

### Tim Stowers era:
1990–1996[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Tim Stowers era: 1990–1996")]

[Tim Stowers](/wiki/Tim_Stowers "Tim Stowers") was hired to succeed Russell
after Georgia Southern's 1989 (15–0) national title. Stowers was the 1989
offensive coordinator, one of only two coordinators since 1900 to direct an
offense of a team with a 15–0 record. However, Stowers was never able to live
up to the expectations set by Russell and was fired in 1995 after a 9–4
record, ranked as one of top 8 teams in 1995 (lost at
[Montana](/wiki/University_of_Montana "University of Montana") the eventual
I-AA/FCS National Champion and beat No. 1-ranked [Troy State](/wiki/Troy_State
"Troy State") 11–0 on the road), by new athletics director Sam Baker, who
never saw Stowers coach a game. Stowers had an overall record of 51–23 (.689)
vs. FCS/I-AA opponents. FBS/D-IA losses-[Miami](/wiki/University_of_Miami
"University of Miami") Hurricanes twice, Georgia Bulldogs,
[Auburn](/wiki/Auburn_University "Auburn University") Tigers, and [Bobby
Bowden](/wiki/Bobby_Bowden "Bobby Bowden") and [Florida
State](/wiki/Florida_State_University "Florida State University") Seminoles.
Stowers had a 6–2 playoff record and a 51–18 (.739) overall record vs.
I-AA/FCS opponents and lower. Stowers won the 1990 I-AA national championship
(12–3) and was named AFCA Kodak National Coach of the Year. He also won
Georgia Southern's first Southern Conference Title in 1993 (first year in the
league) and was named 1993 Southern Conference Coach of the Year. He was
succeeded by interim coach [Frank Ellwood](/wiki/Frank_Ellwood "Frank
Ellwood") for one year. The 1996 season was the first losing season in the
modern era as the Eagles fell to 4–7.

### Paul Johnson era:
1997–2001[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Paul Johnson era: 1997–2001")]

The next coach for the Eagles was [Paul
Johnson](/wiki/Paul_Johnson_\(American_football_coach\) "Paul Johnson
\(American football coach\)"). Johnson found instant success, taking the
Eagles to the playoffs in his first season. He, along with Eagle legend
[Adrian N. Peterson](/wiki/Adrian_N._Peterson "Adrian N. Peterson"), reached
the 1998 national championship. However, the Eagles lost the game to the
[University of Massachusetts](/wiki/UMass "UMass") 55–43 in [Chattanooga,
Tennessee](/wiki/Chattanooga,_Tennessee "Chattanooga, Tennessee"). The Eagles
rebounded under Johnson and won back-to-back national championships in 1999
(vs. [Youngstown State](/wiki/Youngstown_State_University "Youngstown State
University")) and 2000 (vs. [Montana](/wiki/University_of_Montana "University
of Montana")). Both games were played in Chattanooga, Tenn. After the 2001
season, Johnson resigned to become the head coach of [Navy](/wiki/USNA
"USNA").

### Post-Johnson era:
2002–2009[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Post-Johnson era: 2002–2009")]

Johnson was succeeded by Mike Sewak. Despite winning the Southern Conference
championship twice in his tenure, his lack of postseason success as well as a
falling out with former head coach Erk Russell led to his firing after the
[2005 season](/wiki/2005_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2005 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"). [Brian VanGorder](/wiki/Brian_VanGorder
"Brian VanGorder"), a former defensive coordinator at the University of
Georgia, was hired to succeed Sewak. In the first of many controversial moves,
VanGorder scrapped Georgia Southern's famed triple-option offense and did away
with certain traditions, such as the team's arrival at home games on yellow
school buses. Erk Russell had also died unexpectedly of a stroke on the eve
the first game of the [2006
season](/wiki/2006_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2006 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team") after addressing the team on the night before.
VanGorder led the team to a 3–8 record, the worst record at the time in the
modern era of Georgia Southern football. After his unsatisfactory one year as
coach, VanGorder left to take a position with the [Atlanta
Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta Falcons"). Chris Hatcher, formerly the
head coach at [Valdosta State University](/wiki/Valdosta_State_University
"Valdosta State University"), which he led to the 2004 [NCAA Division II
Football Championship](/wiki/NCAA_Division_II_National_Football_Championship
"NCAA Division II National Football Championship"), was named the new head
coach on January 19, 2007. Hatcher led the Eagles back to a winning record
with a 7–4 finish, barely missing the playoffs. However, Hatcher could not
replicate the success of his first season, going 11–11 in the following two
seasons. He was dismissed after the conclusion of the [2009
season](/wiki/2009_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2009 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"), the team's third modern era season with a
losing record at 5–6, and the second within four years.

### Jeff Monken era and final years in the FCS:
2010–2013[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Jeff Monken era and final years in the FCS: 2010–2013")]

On November 29, 2009, school officials announced that Jeff Monken, a longtime
assistant coach under Paul Johnson, would become the next head coach of the
Eagles. Monken's hiring signaled the return of the triple-option offense which
brought success to the program in years past. In Monken's [first
year](/wiki/2010_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2010 Georgia Southern
Eagles football team"), the Eagles finished the regular season with a 7–4
record and made their first playoff appearance since 2005, advancing to the
[semifinals](/wiki/2010_NCAA_Division_I_FCS_football_season#NCAA_FCS_Playoff_bracket
"2010 NCAA Division I FCS football season"), where the Eagles fell to the
[Delaware Blue Hens](/wiki/Delaware_Fightin%27_Blue_Hens_football "Delaware
Fightin' Blue Hens football").

During the [2011 season](/wiki/2011_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team
"2011 Georgia Southern Eagles football team"), Georgia Southern was ranked No.
1 in the FCS for the first time since the 2001 season.[4] Additionally,
Georgia Southern clinched the Southern Conference [Football
Championship](/wiki/List_of_Southern_Conference_football_champions "List of
Southern Conference football champions") for the first time since 2004 and
first time outright since 2002.[5] The Eagles finished the 2011 regular season
with a 9–2 record; however, they were ousted in the
[semifinals](/wiki/2011_NCAA_Division_I_FCS_football_season#NCAA_FCS_Playoff_bracket
"2011 NCAA Division I FCS football season") for a second straight year by the
eventual FCS champion [North Dakota State
Bison](/wiki/2011_North_Dakota_State_Bison_football_team "2011 North Dakota
State Bison football team"). In the [2012
season](/wiki/2012_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2012 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"), the Eagles finished the regular season with
an 8–3 record with a share of the Southern Conference Championship; however,
the Eagles fell for a third straight time in what was ultimately the team's
final FCS playoff game in the [FCS
semifinals](/wiki/2012_NCAA_Division_I_FCS_football_season#NCAA_FCS_Playoff_bracket
"2012 NCAA Division I FCS football season"), losing a rematch of the previous
year's semifinal game against [North Dakota
State](/wiki/2012_North_Dakota_State_Bison_football_team "2012 North Dakota
State Bison football team"). In the team's [final FCS
season](/wiki/2013_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2013 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"), the Eagles compiled a 7–4 record. In the
final game of that season, the Eagles earned an upset win over the [Florida
Gators](/wiki/2013_Florida_Gators_football_team "2013 Florida Gators football
team") 26–20, the team's first win over an FBS opponent in 21 tries. On
December 24, 2013, Monken resigned to become the next head coach of the [Army
Black Knights](/wiki/Army_Black_Knights_football "Army Black Knights
football").[6][7]

### Willie Fritz era and the start of FBS play:
2014–2015[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Willie Fritz era and the start of FBS play: 2014–2015")]

After years of rumors and fan speculation, Georgia Southern announced its
intentions to move to the Football Bowl Subdivision level in April 2012. The
university plans to raise $36.6 million over eight years to accommodate the
move. Paulson Stadium will be expanded to FBS-standards by constructing a
57,000 square feet (5,295 m2) football operations center in the eastern end of
the stadium and adding 6,300 seats on the north stands.[8] Additionally,
students voted in favor of raising student athletic fees by $100 to
accommodate the move. $25 of the fee increase will be used for the stadium
expansion project while the remaining $75 is implemented as the "FBS Fee".[9]

On July 27, 2012, then-Athletics Director Sam Baker resigned. Baker was an
ardent supporter of remaining in the FCS despite university president [Brooks
Keel](/wiki/Brooks_Keel "Brooks Keel")'s proclamation, mainly due to the
financial ramifications of moving to a higher level. On November 12, 2012,
President Keel named Tom Kleinlein as athletics director.[10] On March 27,
2013, Georgia Southern announced its move to the [Sun Belt
Conference](/wiki/Sun_Belt_Conference "Sun Belt Conference") on July 1, 2014,
becoming bowl-eligible in 2015. In the 2013 season, Georgia Southern's
football schedule remained the same, but it was ineligible for the Southern
Conference title as well as the FCS playoffs. The university paid the Southern
Conference $600,000 in exit fees.[11]

On January 10, 2014, [Willie Fritz](/wiki/Willie_Fritz "Willie Fritz"),
formerly the head coach of the [Sam Houston State
Bearkats](/wiki/Sam_Houston_State_Bearkats_football "Sam Houston State
Bearkats football"), was named as the Eagles' ninth modern era head coach and
first of the FBS era.[12] In the Eagles' [first FBS
season](/wiki/2014_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2014 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"), the team finished the season 9–3 overall and
was undefeated in Sun Belt Conference play at 8–0, winning the outright
conference championship. The Eagles became only the third team ever to win a
conference title in its first FBS season, after
[Nevada](/wiki/Nevada_Wolf_Pack_football "Nevada Wolf Pack football") in 1992
([Big West Conference](/wiki/Big_West_Conference "Big West Conference")) and
[Marshall in 1997](/wiki/1997_Marshall_Thundering_Herd_football_team "1997
Marshall Thundering Herd football team") ([Mid-American Conference](/wiki/Mid-
American_Conference "Mid-American Conference")). They were also the first team
ever to go unbeaten in conference play in their first FBS season.[13] Since
the Eagles were under transitional status, the university filed for a
postseason waiver to allow the Eagles to play in a bowl game; however, the
NCAA denied Georgia Southern's waiver request and a subsequent appeal since
enough "full member" FBS teams became bowl-eligible during the season. In the
[2015 season](/wiki/2015_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2015 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team"), Fritz led the Eagles to a 8-4 record,
receiving their first bowl bid to the [GoDaddy
Bowl](/wiki/2015_GoDaddy_Bowl_\(December\) "2015 GoDaddy Bowl \(December\)")
on December 23, 2015 against [Bowling Green](/wiki/Bowling_Green_Falcons
"Bowling Green Falcons").

On December 11, 2015, Fritz resigned as the Eagles head coach to accept the
head coaching position at [Tulane University](/wiki/Tulane_Green_Wave_football
"Tulane Green Wave football").[14] Assistant head coach and running backs
coach Dell McGee was appointed as interim head coach for the GoDaddy Bowl
game, where Georgia Southern defeated Bowling Green 58–27.

### Post-Fritz era:
2016–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Post-Fritz era: 2016–present")]

[Tyson Summers](/wiki/Tyson_Summers "Tyson Summers") was hired on December 21,
2015 to succeed Fritz. In addition to serving as safeties coach for Georgia
Southern during the 2006 season under Brian VanGorder, Summers had previously
served as defensive coordinator and safeties coach at [Colorado
State](/wiki/Colorado_State_Rams_football "Colorado State Rams football") in
2015.[15] During Summers' [first season in
2016](/wiki/2016_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2016 Georgia Southern
Eagles football team"), Georgia Southern suffered its first losing season in
the FBS era, and fourth overall in the modern era.[16] Summers was fired on
October 22, 2017 after starting the [2017
season](/wiki/2017_Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football_team "2017 Georgia
Southern Eagles football team") 0–6. Assistant head coach [Chad
Lunsford](/wiki/Chad_Lunsford "Chad Lunsford") was initially appointed as
interim head coach for the remainder of the season[17] and was officially
named head coach on November 27, 2017.[18] Lunsford finished his first half-
season 2–4, giving the Eagles an overall record of 2–10, the worst record
since football was started in 1924.

##
Stadium[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Stadium")]

Georgia Southern home football games are played at Allen E. Paulson Stadium.
[Paulson Stadium](/wiki/Paulson_Stadium "Paulson Stadium") was dedicated on
September 29, 1984, and has an official seating capacity of 25,000. The record
attendance was on September 17, 2016 in the Georgia Southern-University
Louisiana Monroe game.The Eagles beat UL Monroe 23-21 and set a new attendance
record of 25,735. Prior to the Eagles' first FBS season, Paulson Stadium
underwent a major expansion project that includes the addition of a new
football operations center and an addition of more than 6,000 new seats.

##
Awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Awards")]

The Eagles have won six [NCAA](/wiki/NCAA "NCAA") FCS National Championships,
the most by any team in the nation.

### National
championships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: National championships")]

  * **1985** – Coach Erk Russell and the Eagles won their first national championship vs. Furman University in the Tacoma Dome in Tacoma, Washington. Quarterback Tracy Ham threw for 419 yards and rushed for another 90 to overcome a 28–6 deficit.
  * **1986** – The Eagles returned to Tacoma to defeat the Arkansas State Indians. Tracy Ham earned 486 rushing and passing yards and three touchdowns.
  * **1989** – In Erk Russell's final game, the Eagles defeated Stephen F. Austin in Statesboro, Georgia, in front of 25,725 fans to complete a perfect 15–0 season. Quarterback Raymond Gross engineered 17 fourth-quarter points, including a game-winning field goal with 1:41 remaining in the game.
  * **1990** – Tim Stowers' Eagles win their fourth national championship vs. Nevada
  * **1999** – Paul Johnson won his first national championship in Chattanooga, Tennessee, vs. Youngstown State in [Jim Tressel's](/wiki/Jim_Tressel "Jim Tressel") last national championship game as a Penguin (Jim Tressel's last game as a Penguin was against the Richmond Spiders in the playoffs in 2000). Adrian Peterson ran for a championship game record 247 yards on 25 carries and scored three touchdowns.
  * **2000** – The Eagles defeated the Montana Grizzlies to win their sixth and final FCS championship.

### National runners-
up[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: National runners-up")]

  * **1988** – The Eagles lost to [Furman University](/wiki/Furman_University "Furman University") in [Pocatello, Idaho](/wiki/Pocatello,_Idaho "Pocatello, Idaho").
  * **1998** – In Paul Johnson's first national championship game, the Eagles lost to [UMass](/wiki/UMass "UMass").

### Walter Payton
Award[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Walter Payton Award")]

Georgia Southern is one of five schools to have multiple [Walter Payton
Award](/wiki/Walter_Payton_Award "Walter Payton Award") winners honoring the
top offensive player in the Football Championships Subdivision. Running Back
[Adrian Peterson](/wiki/Adrian_N._Peterson "Adrian N. Peterson") won the award
in 1999 and quarterback [Jayson Foster](/wiki/Jayson_Foster "Jayson Foster")
won it in 2007.

### Eddie Robinson/AFCA Kodak Coach of the Year
Award[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Eddie Robinson/AFCA Kodak Coach of the Year Award")]

Two Georgia Southern coaches have won the [Eddie Robinson
Award](/wiki/Eddie_Robinson_Award "Eddie Robinson Award") winners honoring the
top coach in Division I-FCS. Erk Russell won it in 1989 and Paul Johnson in
1998. Tim Stowers also won the 1990 AFCA Kodak Coach of the Year Award voted
on by his peers. Same award with a name change, with all three of the
aforementioned voted on by the (AFCA) American Football Coaches Association
membership.

##
Traditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Traditions")]

###
Nickname[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Nickname")]

The athletics teams of Georgia Southern University are referred to as the
Eagles. However, the school has gone by a number of different nicknames. From
as early as 1907 the teams of the then First District A&M school were referred
to as the Culture to reflect the agricultural background of the school.[19]
From 1924 to 1941, the nickname was the Blue Tide. After World War II,
athletic teams were referred to as the Professors reflecting the school's
status as a teacher-training college. However, in 1959 when the school was
renamed Georgia Southern College, a student vote was held to determine the new
[mascot](/wiki/Mascot "Mascot"); among the 104 entries, voters chose Eagles
over Colonels by a narrow margin. In 1997, a contest was held to select the
official name of the mascot, incoming freshman Imen Edmond and Heidi Barber
won with the name GUS.[20]

### Beautiful Eagle
Creek[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Beautiful Eagle Creek")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Eagle_Creek_%28Georgia%29.jpg/220px-
Eagle_Creek_%28Georgia%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eagle_Creek_\(Georgia\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eagle_Creek_\(Georgia\).jpg "Enlarge")

Beautiful Eagle Creek

When Georgia Southern resurrected football in 1981, it lacked tradition. A
drainage ditch that the team had to cross several times a day during football
practice came to be called Beautiful Eagle Creek by Coach Erk Russell. When
the Eagles traveled to Northern Iowa during the 1985 playoffs, Russell took
along a jug of this Eagle Creek water to sprinkle on the field.

### The Hugo
Bowl[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: The Hugo Bowl")]

In 1989 ESPN was to broadcast a Thursday Night Football game between Georgia
Southern and the [Middle Tennessee State Blue
Raiders](/wiki/Middle_Tennessee_State_Blue_Raiders "Middle Tennessee State
Blue Raiders"). However, [Hurricane Hugo](/wiki/Hurricane_Hugo "Hurricane
Hugo"), a category 4 storm, was headed straight toward the coast of Georgia.
Hugo ranked as the 11th most intense hurricane at time of landfall to strike
the United States this century, with the highest ever recorded storm surge on
the East Coast. Nevertheless, the decision was made to continue with the game.
For safety purposes, an open line was kept between the press box at Paulson
Stadium and the National Hurricane Center in Florida. The Eagles went on to
defeat MTSU by a score of 26–0 in a classic that will forever be known in
Eagle history as the Hugo Bowl.

This was the first night game played at Paulson Stadium. Temporary lighting
was used for the game because the stadium was not outfitted with permanent
lighting until the 1994 season. Many feared that the booms used to hoist the
stadium lights would tip over due to the heavy wind. While it was expected
initially to be a sellout crowd, due to the approaching storm the actual
attendance was in the neighborhood of only 3,000.

### Plain
uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Plain uniforms")]

The uniforms consist of plain white pants, blue helmets with a white stripe
down the middle and the player's number on the sides, and blue jerseys. This
minimalist look was adopted more or less out of necessity. When the program
was revived in 1982, the school did not have a large budget. Indeed, the
equipment budget was so limited that only plain white practice pants could be
purchased. Hence, the practice pants doubled as game pants. Russell bought
solid blue helmets and had the players put a piece of tape down the
middle.[21] With the subsequent success of the Eagles, the basic design has
remained the same, with the only real changes in recent years being a white
stripe down the middle of the helmets and the addition of names to the backs
of the jerseys. Sports Illustrated has ranked the uniforms as being the third
best in college football.

### Yellow school
buses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Yellow school buses")]

When the football program was restarted in 1981, money was tight. In fact,
there wasn't enough money to furnish transportation to home games. The
[Bulloch County](/wiki/Bulloch_County "Bulloch County") school system sold two
buses for a dollar each to the team. The buses have been used by the team ever
since as transportation to [Allen E. Paulson Stadium](/wiki/Paulson_Stadium
"Paulson Stadium"). This tradition continued even when the Eagles rose to
powerhouse status. This briefly ended with the arrival of Brian VanGorder,
following his scrapping of the Eagles' triple-option rushing attack. The
tradition was revived after VanGorder's departure.

### Black
flag[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Southern_Eagles_football&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Black flag")]

In 2011, Coach Jeff Monken's team took the field leading with a solid black
flag. The flag symbolized their motto "No quarter given, no quarter taken."
During the game it was placed behind the bench. The flag was carried by safety
Derek Heyden, who suffered a career ending neck injury early in the season.
